description: From Middle English *ogeve, egeve, egeove, from Old French œgive, ogive, augive, from Late Latin augiva, of uncertain origin; compare Late Latin ogis (“a support, prop”), Latin augeō (“to increase, strengthen”), Spanish auge (“highest point of power or fortune, apogee”). Doublet of ogive.

entries.meaning: (architecture) A double curve in the shape of an elongated S; an object of that shape.
(architecture) A pointed arch made from two ogees.
(aesthetic facial surgery) The malar or cheekbone prominence transitioning into the mid-cheek hollow.
(distillation) The bubble-shaped chamber of a pot still that connects the swan neck to the pot and allows distillate to expand, condense, and fall back into the pot.
